docs.lead_paragraph: San Diego is caught in a financial bind, facing the possibility of a bankruptcy filing, largely because of a $1.2 billion shortfall in its pension fund for municipal workers. For years the city has spent money from illusory pension fund earnings, according to the authors of a new report released yesterday. Yet the practice, which the authors called dangerous, is sanctioned by law in California and other places and is commonplace among cities that offer pensions to their workers. The findings raise the possibility that other communities will face similar financial disasters.

headline.main: Budget Use Of Pensions Sows Trouble In San Diego

docs.abstract: San Diego is caught in financial bind, facing possibility of bankruptcy filing, largely because of $1.2 billion shortfall in its pension fund for municipal workers; report by Paul S Maco and Richard Carl Sauer calls city's practice of spending money from illusory pension fund earnings dangerous; practice is sanctioned by law in California and other places ans is commonplace among cities that offer pensions to their workers; at core of San Diego's problems is its use of pension fund earnings that exceeded projections to pay for variety of local projects, including expenses associated with playing host to 1996 Republican National Convention and paying health insurance premiums for retired teachers and firefighters; photo (M)
docs.snippet: San Diego faces the possibility of a bankruptcy filing because of a shortfall in its pension fund, but the practice is commonplace among other cities.

docs.lead_paragraph: Over objections from some drug companies, the Bush administration unveiled a new feature of a federal Web site on Wednesday comparing prices for similar brand-name drugs that can be used to treat conditions like high blood pressure, high cholesterol, arthritis and allergies. The information, compiled originally for Medicare beneficiaries, is available to all consumers at www.medicare.gov.

headline.main: Price Comparison for Drugs Is Put on Federal Web Site

docs.abstract: Bush administration unveils new feature of federal Web site comparing prices for similar brand-name drugs that can be used to treat variety of conditions; federal health officials say doctors and patients could use data to choose less expensive drugs providing benefits similar or identical to those of high-cost medications (M)
docs.snippet: Over objections from some drug companies, the Bush administration unveiled a new feature on the Medicare Web site comparing prices for similar brand-name drugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Stewart Seeks to Begin Her Prison Term Soon Saying she wished to ''put this nightmare behind me,'' Martha Stewart said she wanted to enter a federal prison as soon as possible to begin serving her five-month sentence without waiting to see whether an appeals court would overturn her conviction on conspiracy and other charges earlier this year. ''I am very sad knowing I will miss the holiday season,'' Ms. Stewart said at a news conference, ticking off Halloween, Thanksgiving and Christmas as celebrations she will have to observe behind bars. [Page A1.]
docs.snippet: Stewart Seeks to Begin Her Prison Term Soon  Saying she wished to ''put this nightmare behind me,'' Martha Stewart said she wanted to enter a federal prison as soon as possible to begin serving her five-month sentence without waiting to see whether...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the biggest test yet of an idea central to the Bush administration's health care policy, the government will offer more than three million federal employees and their families a new type of high-deductible health insurance that includes tax-free savings accounts, the federal Office of Personnel Management said yesterday. Aetna, one of the nation's largest insurers, would take the lead, providing the insurance and administering the plans for federal employees in 32 states and the District of Columbia. Seventeen other insurers, including the Government Employees Hospital Association and the Mail Handlers Benefit Plan, will also offer the savings plans, as will Coventry Health Care in several states.

headline.main: A Health Insurance Option Coming to Federal Workers

docs.abstract: US Office of Personnel Management says government will offer more than three million federal employees and their families new type of high-deductible health insurance that includes tax-free savings accounts, biggest test yet of idea central to Bush administration's health care policy; Aetna will take lead, providing insurance and administering plans for federal employees in 32 states and District of Columbia; 17 other insurers, including Government Employees Hospital Association and Mail Handlers Benefit Plan, will also offer savings plans, as will Coventry Health Care in several states (M)
docs.snippet: In the biggest test yet of an idea central to the Bush administration's health care policy, the government will offer more than three million federal employees and their families a new type of high-deductible health insurance that includes tax-free...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration came out Tuesday in opposition to Democratic proposals to hold down the scheduled 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums next year, saying that a one-year freeze would lead to much higher premiums in 2006. Dr. Mark B. McClellan, administrator of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said the premiums would rise 20 percent in 2006 if Congress blocked the increase planned for next year. Under current law, the monthly premium is scheduled to be $78.20 next year, up $11.60 from the premium this year. In most cases, the amount is deducted from Social Security checks.

headline.main: Bush Administration Opposes Move to Delay Medicare Premium Increase

docs.abstract: Bush administration comes out in opposition to Democratic proposals to hold down scheduled 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums next year, saying that one-year freeze would lead to much higher premiums in 2006; Dr Mark B McClellan, administrator of federal centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, says premiums would rise 20 percent in 2006 if Congress blocks increase planned for next year; under current law, monthly premium is scheduled to be $78.20 next year, up $11.60 from premium this year; in most cases, amount is deducted from Social Security checks (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration said that Democratic proposals to hold down the scheduled 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums next year would lead to much higher premiums in 2006.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new environmental study of the former Deutsche Bank building opposite ground zero, independent of the bank and its insurers, has confirmed the presence of high levels of asbestos, dioxin, lead and other contaminants throughout the unused 40-story tower. The study was conducted by the Louis Berger Group for the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which took over the building on Aug. 31 and plans to begin razing it by the end of the year. Though it has long been known that the tower was contaminated, the findings released yesterday will almost certainly add to the expense and complication -- both structurally and politically -- of dismantling the building.

headline.main: 9/11 Contamination Is High At Bank Tower, Study Says

docs.abstract: New environmental study conducted for Lower Manhattan Development Corp confirms presence of high levels of asbestos, dioxin and lead throughout unused 40-story Deutsche Bank building opposite ground zero; findings will add to expense and complication, both structurally and politically, of LMDC plan to dismantle building; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A new study of the former Deutsche Bank building opposite ground zero has confirmed contaminants throughout the tower.

byline.original: By DAVID W. DUNLAP; Colin Moynihan contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: They wanted to know about today's war, not one fought 35 years ago. President Bush's decision not to mention the debate over his own Vietnam-era military service when he addressed the National Guard Association on Tuesday came as a relief to many in the audience, who said they had grown weary with all the public rehashing of that war.

headline.main: At National Guard Meeting, It's Today's War That Matters

docs.abstract: National Guard members listening to Pres Bush at gathering in Las Vegas say they are relieved that he did not mention debate over his own Vietnam war-era service, and prefer to discuss getting troops home safely from Iraq; photo; some are quietly skeptical about Bush's policies (S)
docs.snippet: President Bush's decision not to mention the debate over his own Vietnam-era military service when he addressed the National Guard Association came as a relief to many in the audience.

byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY; Joe Schoenmann contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Canada Looks for Ways to Fix Its Health Care System'' (news article, Sept. 12):
docs.abstract: Letter from Mark Hannay of Health Care for All campaign says problems in America's health care system arise from both delivery and insurance systems; calls for comprehensive, affordable health coverage for all (Sept 12 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Canada Looks for Ways to Fix Its Health Care System'' (news article, Sept. 12):

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John Kerry ratcheted up his character-based critique of President Bush on Tuesday, turning health-care forums here and in Milwaukee into attacks on his opponent's honesty. Mr. Kerry accused the Bush administration of manipulating reports to obscure the fact that Medicare premiums will eat up 37 percent of the average person's Social Security income by 2006.

headline.main: Kerry Says Washington Hides Medicare's Cost to People

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry ratchets up his character-based critique of Pres Bush, turning health-care forums in Toledo, Ohio, and Milwaukee into attacks on his opponent's honesty; accuses Bush administration of manipulating reports to obscure fact that Medicare premiums will eat up 37 percent of average person's Social Security income by 2006; photo (M)
docs.snippet: John Kerry accused the Bush administration of manipulating reports to obscure the fact that Medicare premiums will eat up 37 percent of the average person's Social Security income by 2006.

byline.original: By JODI WILGOREN; Randal C. Archibold contributed reporting from Oregon City, Ore., for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed gay rights legislation into law Monday, requiring insurance companies doing business in California to offer the same health coverage to registered same-sex partners as they do to married couples. ''This is proof that the governor meant what he said when he said he wanted to be the governor for all Californians,'' said Lorri L. Jean, chief executive of the L.A. Gay and Lesbian Center. The new law does not extend to unmarried heterosexual couples under age 62. Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Gay Rights Insurance Law Signed

docs.abstract: California Gov Arnold Schwarzenegger signs gay rights legislation requiring insurance companies doing business in California to offer same health coverage to registered same-sex couples as they do to married couples (S)
